description: From pike +‎ -er. In some senses, it has been linked etymologically to the word pikey as well as to Pike County in eastern Missouri [1]. In the latter instance the term originally denoted poor immigrants to California.

entries.meaning: (military, historical) A soldier armed with a pike, a pikeman.
examples: Upstairs in a waiting room there were pikers whose tunics echoed Baudricourt′s gold lion shield painted up and down the rafters.

entries.meaning: One who bets or gambles only with small amounts of money.
examples: Bud swelled his chest and laid his hand on Jeff′s shoulder. “Just to show you I′m not a piker,” he cried recklessly, “I′ll bet you twenty-five dollars I can beat your Skeeter with my Smoky horse that I rode in here. Is it a go?”
“And if you′ve got to be a piker,” said Dolly, “don′t be ashamed to be a piker. We′re not spending a hundred dollars because we can afford it, but because you dreamt a dream.”

entries.meaning: (Australia) A bullock living in the wild. (Also used attributively.) [from 19th c.]
examples: ‘There's always a few old piker bullocks find their way into this country. But mostly cattle don't come this far.’

entries.meaning: (Australia, New Zealand, slang) One who refuses to go out with friends, or leaves a party early; a spoilsport or "chicken". [from 20th c.]
examples: Mate, don't be a piker! Come to Angie′s birthday party tonight!

entries.meaning: (Australia, New Zealand, slang) One who pikes (quits or backs out of a promise).
(US, dated) A male freshman at Cornell University.
